text: VSCode still isn't generally ready though. There are quite a few missing things. Too many for deep work :shrug: but you could get away with it in a pinch

elements.text: VSCode still isn't generally ready though. There are quite a few missing things. Too many for deep work
but you could get away with it in a pinch

text:
I think that’s pretty debatable; I’ve used VSCode with the Julia extension every day for my work since last May without an issue. I mostly just use the syntax highlighting and linting though, since I’m usually in a tmux session ssh’d to an ec2 instance anyway, so can’t really use many of the extension features. I’ve found VSCode way better than Atom personally, because it’s less laggy/buggy, and the remote features are way better.

Anyway I’m not saying you should change your video or anything, I’m just saying I don’t think “not suitable for deep work” is broadly applicable and is more related to your personal workflow than anything else.

elements.text:

I mostly just use the syntax highlighting and linting though, since I’m usually in a tmux session ssh’d to an ec2 instance anyway, so can’t really use many of the extension features. I’ve found VSCode way better than Atom personally, because it’s less laggy/buggy, and the remote features are way better.

Anyway I’m not saying you should change your video or anything, I’m just saying I don’t think “not suitable for deep work” is broadly applicable and is more related to your personal workflow than anything else.

text: I don't think it's debatable to say it's very incomplete when comparing against Juno. I immediately found and opened 10 issues the first time using it. I use it for remote now, slowly integrating it more into my workflow, but the reason why I don't use it more is mostly because of the bugs and incomplete features. If you sit down and check the boxes one basically supersets the other. I agree VSCode is less laggy so I hope and know it will get there, but using both simultaneously like I'm doing really makes the feature completeness issue front and center as one generally has everything an IDE needs while the other still has trouble showing profiles :shrug:

text: I'd give a year, but right now I have it set for remote to play around with it, but I wouldn't recommend it to someone who's not hardcore yet. I mean, the group here is definitely the Vim/Emacs/VSCode on Arch Linux crowd, so it's a different general crew.

text: I think all those criticisms are fair, just objected to the “deep work” bit :slightly_smiling_face:. Probably I misinterpreted it.

text:
It seems only 3 issues are now open from the <https://github.com/julia-vscode/julia-vscode/issues/1544>, so the progress is definitely there and hopefully it will all get resolved soon.
I also wait till there are more issues closed in VSCode before migrating.

text: A lot of it isn't the fault of the Julia devs. I think a big portion is that they are waiting on the VSCode Jupyter integration, which will basically choose a lot of new defaults for keyboard shortcuts and windowing that they can build off of. Until then though :shrug:

text: I also use vscode for at least a half a year now, what do you miss from vscode? :open_mouth:

elements.text: I also use vscode for at least a half a year now, what do you miss from vscode?

text: See the issue list. Profiler mangles outputs, most key commands aren't there (the hold up is that it's waiting on the VS Code Jupyter), interrupts are not completely integrated yet, treeviews are not fully integrated, etc.
